summary: This is a government memorandum filed by the Acting U.S. Attorney opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed motion for pretrial release on bail. It argues she remains an extreme flight risk due to the seriousness of the charges, strength of evidence, her extensive foreign ties and financial resources, and demonstrated ability to live in hiding. The document references the initial bail hearing and detention order from July 2020.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with facilitating the sexual abuse of minors by Jeffrey Epstein and with perjury. The government argues she is a severe flight risk and should remain detained.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier with whom Maxwell allegedly conspired to entice, groom, and transport minors for illegal sex acts. His will includes a grant to Maxwell.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The government attorney who submitted this memorandum in opposition to Maxwell's bail motion.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.context: Referred to as Maxwell's spouse. The document questions the state of their marriage, notes he refused to come forward initially, and discusses assets transferred to him.

persons.name: Hans Peterson
persons.context: Cited as an example of a dual U.S.-French citizen who was not extradited from France to the U.S. despite confessing to murder.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to entice, groom, and transport minor girls for illegal sex acts between approximately 1994 and 1997.
Married, though the document notes inconsistent statements about their marital status and that Maxwell transferred significant assets to him via trusts.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is prosecuting Maxwell and opposing her release in this memorandum.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Bail Hearing and Detention Order
events.description: The court held a lengthy bail hearing and subsequently ordered Maxwell detained pending trial, finding her a serious flight risk.

events.title: Renewed Motion for Release
events.description: Maxwell's defense team filed a renewed motion for release on bail.

events.title: Alleged Criminal Scheme
events.description: The period during which Maxwell is alleged to have facilitated Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of multiple minor victims.

events.title: Maxwell Living in Hiding
events.description: In the year leading to her arrest, Maxwell lived in isolation in New Hampshire, using an alias, concealed assets, and evaded detection.

keyFacts: The government asserts Maxwell has access to approximately $22 million in assets, far more than the $3.8 million she initially reported to Pretrial Services.
France's Ministry of Justice confirmed in writing that France does not extradite its citizens to the United States, a key factor in the flight risk assessment.
Maxwell demonstrated a sophisticated ability to live in hiding, using an alias to purchase property, concealing assets in trusts, and evading media and law enforcement for a year.
Jeffrey Epstein's will includes a $10 million cash grant to Ghislaine Maxwell.
Multiple victims of the alleged abuse have asked the government to convey their support for Maxwell's continued detention.
